results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 04
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for and broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew Mackenzie, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The program’s style makes the avant-garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew takes us to the RMIT Gallery where an exhibition by political/journalist cartoonists is taking place. This is then followed by a visit to The Photographers’ Gallery; the Penthouse and Pavement “Graveyard Boys and Cemetery Girls” Exhibition (horror culture); Gertrude Street Galleries “Angled 2002” Exhibition by Natasha Johns-Messenger; West Space “Suburban myth” Exhibition and finally an interview with video artist Robin Hely.

results.title: Public hangings. Series 1. Ep. 05
results.brief_description: Public hangings is a local television program on the arts produced for broadcast on community television (channel 31) in Melbourne, Australia from 2002. Enjoying a cult following, the program produced by Irish art critic and London gallery director, Andrew Mackenzie, roams the streets of Melbourne in search of opening nights and visual vox pops. The programs style makes the avant-garde accessible and provides an insight into a vibrant underground city culture. In this episode Andrew explores Melbourne’s city lane ways, many of which offer public access to street art. He visits City Lights, venue for a a Public Art Project; interviews the author of “Spray Can Art” Jim Prigoff at the Central Station Mural; attends the opening night at Bus Gallery; meets and talks to Mark Amerika at CCP to discuss Amerika’s “Filmtext” (Web Art) Exhibition at the e-Media Gallery and ends the program with an interview with video artist Laresa Kosloff.

results.title: Marvellous Melbourne
results.creator_credit: Spencer Productions and Charles Cozens Spencer
results.brief_description: In this silent film approximately 15 static and moving shots, including those from a cable car, are separated by intertitles. They take on a Lumiere look with the way that they picture Melbourne’s main streets and buildings that were prominent at the time. The different fashion and the horse and cart transportation are even more fascinating in this familiar setting.

results.title: November = Novembre
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly and Robert Nichol
results.brief_description: A hundred and one lingering, luminous impressions of the month when the ripe fullness of the Canadian autumn wilts and the whole earth seems to settle into brooding calm. This is a cine-poem, reflecting the somber moods of November, the still, waiting separateness when the Canadian year dawdles, hangs back from the hour when the first snowfall will make all things even. But from the muted tones of the dying season emerges a new, stark beauty. Film without words. (Contains images of duck hunting and animial skinning that may offend some viewers.)

results.title: The Vision of William Blake (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Morse Films, British Film Institute Experimental Film Fund and Guy Brenton
results.brief_description: Filmed in four museums that contain major collections of Blake’s writings and paintings, this documentary by Guy Brenton explores the anguish of Blake’s prophetic world, Music by Ralph Vaughan Williams, and narration and poems read by Bernard Miles and Robert Speight.

results.title: Just Peanuts
results.brief_description: In Australia, peanuts are grown at Kingaroy, Queensland. The film shows how they reach down from the stalks to grow under the soil, how they are harvested and left to dry in the hot sun. The many uses of peanuts are illustrated, including the surprising number of by-products such as fabrics, coffee substitute, cosmetics and high quality soap.

results.title: A Scary Time
results.creator_credit: UNICEF, Thorold Dickinson, Shirley Clarke and Robert Hughes
results.brief_description: A powerful emotional plea by the United Nation’s Children Fund, appealing for support from affluent nations using experimental film techniques combining found and improvised footage. The film intercuts footage of American children during their Halloween ‘Trick or Treat’ rounds collecting money for UNICEF with footage of international child hunger. Deals convincingly with the realities of children’s lives in less affluent countries. Music by Peggy Glanville-Hicks.

results.title: Gippsland Honeymoon
results.brief_description:
A honeymoon couple tour the Gippsland area and admire the scenic attractions of the country-side. Depicts many of Victoria’s famous tourist attractions including: Lakes Entrance, Gippsland, Orbost, the Snowy River, the Tambo River, Bairnsdale, Omeo, Walhalla Goldfields, Buchan Caves, Mallacoota Inlet, La Trobe Valley, Glen Maggie Weir and Ninety Mile Beach. Produced in conjunction with The Tourist Development Authority and The Gippsland Lakes and Tourist Promotion Council.

This film was discussed on ABC Gippsland Radio on 14 March 2020. The following are comments for viewers which add insight into the film

Martin Richardson “Joe” is Joe Southon, from Paynesville who wasn’t actually a Lakes Entrance fisherman, but was the chosen “talent” for the movie - it was through his connections that the film crew came down here to make the movie. He was a farmer, part-time fisherman, and farm manager whose property occupied a large part of what is now the town of Paynesville. He was also involved in many civic roles around the Bairnsdale Shire. His daughter Beryl and son Bluey still live in Paynesville.

Ashley Meek My father features on this add fishing at the Glenmaggie spillway

Neil Walters who picked up one of the narrators was Ross Higgins. “put the money on the fridge wog.!” (Kingswood Country)

Graeme Nixon Cape Conran my dad jim nixon boat and me. Front boat
